title: Scenes from Eutaw: A treasure-trove of antebellum homes
text:
Comments 
After many years of traveling through Alabama and passing the sign with the intriguing name "Eutaw," I finally had the opportunity to visit the small west-central Alabama town. I knew from my online research that it was chock-full of antebellum structures and had my camera ready. 
Turns out, the town of fewer than 2,800 souls contains 27 pre-Civil War buildings, including the impressive Kirkwood Manor, a plantation home begun in 1857 and still unfinished at the end of the Civil War. 
The beginnings of Eutaw 
Eutaw is the seat of Greene County, located in what is known as the Black Belt region of the state, named for its dark, rich soil. The settlement, founded in 1819, was initially called Mesopotamia, a name still found on the town's historic cemetery. In 1838, citizens decided to move the county seat from Erie to Mesopotamia and felt the town needed a new name. 
According to the Encyclopedia of Alabama , Eutaw is named for a Revolutionary War event. "The city is named for the Battle of Eutaw Springs, a decisive battle in the American Revolution in which troops led by war hero Nathaniel Greene (for whom the county is named) recaptured Charleston, S.C., from the British." Because of its location near the Warrior River, Eutaw was a shipping and cotton hub in the first half of the 19 th century. Like many once-bustling towns, Eutaw suffered economically during Reconstruction. 
Today, despite some empty storefronts in its quaint downtown and some historic homes in need of restoration, Eutaw is a draw for tourists interested in its antebellum history. 
The Eutaw Formation 
Eutaw has an interesting history below-ground, as well. A geologic feature that runs beneath parts of Alabama, Georgia and Mississippi is known as the Eutaw Formation because the greatest portion of the formation lies near the surface in Eutaw. Dozens of Upper Cretaceous fossils – including dinosaurs, mosasaurs and pterosaur – have been unearthed in the formation. 
Kirkwood Manor 
Kirkwood is a Greek Revival-style mansion with Italianate influences, including a large cupola. According to RuralSWAlabama.org , the house features two floors topped by the cupola and a portico with Ionic columns on two sides of the home. 
The most intriguing aspect of the beautiful home is that it was begun in 1857 and basically remained unfinished for more than 100 years, until the 1970s. Foster M. Kirksey, a cotton planter and broker, was nearing completion of the home when the Civil War began. Because Kirksey lost much of his fortune in the war, he was unable to add the luxurious finishing touches he had planned, or even to maintain it properly. 
RuralSWAlabama explains: "The house remained in the Kirksey family until 1961. In 1972, Roy and Mary Swayze bought the home and began renovations with Mr. Swayze doing much of the work himself. When the Swayzes painted the home in 1977, it was its first coat of paint since 1912 and took 200 gallons of paint." 
The Swayzes spent 15 years restoring Kirkwood and were awarded a National Trust for Historic Preservation Honor Award in 1982. 
"Scenes from ..." is a photo feature of small towns throughout Alabama. To suggest a town to be featured, email Kelly Kazek at kkazek@al.com . Follow her Scenes from Alabama Towns on Pinterest.
